title: Facebook not worried about $5 billion FTC fine
text: Facebook’s eye-popping $5 billion FTC fine may have set a record, but it’s a drop in the bucket for owner Mark Zuckerberg. Zuckerberg, who has a net worth of $79.8 billion according to Bloomberg, could pay the fine out-of-pocket and still remain comfortably placed as the fifth-richest man in the world.

title: Facebook's (FB) CEO Mark Zuckerberg on Q2 2019 Results - Earnings Call Transcript
text: Facebook's (FB) CEO Mark Zuckerberg on Q2 2019 Results - Earnings Call Transcript

title: Facebook’s earnings hit by fines and growth slowdown, but investors remain unfazed
text: Facebook Inc. has taken a hit of over $5 billion to its earnings in the first half of the year to pay government fines, and on Wednesday it predicted its revenue growth will slow down in the second half of the year.

title: Facebook Needs Greater Focus on Privacy, FTC Commissioner Phillips Says
text: U.S. Federal Trade Commission Commissioner Noah Phillips comments on the FTC's opening of a formal antitrust investigation into Facebook Inc. and the social-media giant's agreement to pay $5 billion to resolve an investigation into years of privacy violations. He speaks with Bloomberg's Emily Chang on "Bloomberg Technology."

title: 9 reasons the Facebook FTC settlement is a joke
text: The FTC just announced the details of its settlement agreement with Facebook over years of privacy practices in violation of a previous order. To say the settlement is favorable to Facebook, even with the record $5 billion penalty, is an understatement; the company's lawyers are probably popping champagne right about now.

title: Facebook Is Proving to Be the Teflon Company, EMarketer Analyst Says
text: Debra Aho Williamson, EMarketer principal analyst, and Techonomy founder David Kirkpatrick break down Facebook Inc.'s second-quarter earnings and react to the social-media company's disclosure that the U.S. Federal Trade Commission has opened a formal antitrust investigation into its business. They speak with Bloomberg's Emily Chang  on "Bloomberg Technology."

title: Earnings bonanza: 6 trades
text: The "Fast Money" traders give you 6 trades in the multitude of stocks that reported earnings today.

title: Facebook Earnings: Revenue Growth Rate Accelerates

title: Explainer: What Google, Facebook, Amazon & Apple could face in U.S. antitrust probe
text: The U.S. Department of Justice is investigating whether big technology companies are engaged in anticompetitive behavior, addressing a rising tide of criticism they have become too powerful to the detriment of consumers.

text: Facebook's second-quarter earnings were positive overall as sales topped expectations, while DAUs and MAUs were in line. FB stock increased.

text: Facebook’s investors were not phased by the announcement of a $5 billion FTC fine after baking it into share price expectations, but Facebook’s admission that it was not under investigation by the FTC over antitrust issues was a surprise. title: Facebook Rises Despite $5 Billion FTC Privacy Charge
text: Facebook Inc. (NASDAQ:FB), a major social media platform, said on Wednesday that despite recording a significant Federal Trade Commission privacy charge, revenues for the second quarter outperformed analyst estimates on continued growth in the user base and high average revenue per user.

title: Facebook earnings include admission of two antitrust probes and billions in fines, but stock still gains
text: An antitrust probe of big tech, a record Federal Trade Commission settlement, another settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission, confirmation that it is being investigated by the FTC and Department of Justice — none of it seems to faze Facebook Inc.

title: Facebook Stock Falls, Recovers After $5 Billion Fine Over Privacy
text:
Facebook stock initially fell 2.5% then recovered after agreeing to a $5 billion penalty and sweeping new restrictions imposed by the Federal Trade Commission over privacy issues Wednesday.
The post Facebook Stock Falls, Recovers After $5 Billion Fine Over Privacy appeared first on Investor's Business Daily.
